questions.text: Identify the liver segment from the given image which gets hypertrophied in liver cirrhosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Segment 1 corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver.
  • In liver cirrhosis, due to relative sparing of its venous drainage (directly into the IVC), caudate lobe hypertrophy is a classic finding.
  • This compensatory hypertrophy can cause the caudate lobe to appear prominent, and may even indent the IVC in advanced cases.

Frequent findings in advanced cirrhosis include hypertrophy of the caudate lobe (Segment 1 ) and lateral segments of the left lobe (segments 2 and 3) with concomitant atrophy of the posterior segments (6 and 7) of the right lobe.

These changes are likely related to changes in blood flow between the segments.


Explanation of other options:

Segment 4 (Option B): Medial segment of left lobe; does not typically hypertrophy in cirrhosis.

Segment 5 (Option C): Anterior segment of the right lobe; usually affected by fibrotic atrophy.

Segment 7 (Option D): Posterior segment of the right lobe; not commonly hypertrophied in cirrhosis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a cystic lesion in the liver on USG, which is shown below and was diagnosed as a case of liver abscess. Which of the following locations to be additionally evaluated to identify the source of the abscess?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatic abscesses are localised collections of necrotic inflammatory tissue caused by bacterial, parasitic, or fungal agents.
  • Hepatic abscesses can occur via different routes, such as :
    • hematogenous spread of infection via the portal vein or hepatic arteries
    • biliary spread of infection from ascending cholangitis or cholecystitis
    • direct inoculation in the setting of penetrating trauma or iatrogenic following a procedure
  • The ileocaecal junction and caecum should be evaluated to find out the amoebic involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Spleen (Option A): Not a primary source of infection for liver abscess.

Stomach (Option C): Usually not involved in amoebic transmission.

Pancreas (Option D): Associated with pseudocysts, not with typical infective liver abscesses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with mild fever and right upper quadrant pain, and bloody diarrhoea for the past 7 days. On ultrasound, there is a hypoechoic lesion with irregular borders in the posterosuperior aspect of the right lobe of the liver. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above USG finding and clinical Scenario is suggestive of Amoebic Liver Abscess.
  • It presents with Mild Fever, RUQ pain, & Bloody diarrhoea and presents as a Single Hypoechoic lesion with irregular borders on CT.
  • It is treated by Metronidazole and Paromomycin.
  • Liver abscess shows the Double rim sign on CT.

Explanation of other options:

Pyogenic Liver Abscess (Option B): Usually presents with more systemic toxicity; ultrasound may show multiple or septated lesions with internal echoes.

Hydatid Cysts (Option C) are caused by Echinococcus granulosus.WHO classification is used for hydatid cysts.

Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) (Option D) shows early enhancement and Rapid washout in the triple-phase CT Scan.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male veterinarian presented to the OPD with abdominal pain and vomiting. On undergoing a USG examination, the following image of the liver was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ultrasound image shows a multiloculated cyst with internal serpiginous membranes, classically described as the "water lily sign", highly suggestive of a hydatid cyst.
  • The patient's occupation as a veterinarian raises the risk of Echinococcus granulosus infection due to close contact with animals.
  • The liver is the most common site for hydatid disease.
  • The detached endocyst membranes seen within the cystic cavity are diagnostic of hydatid cyst rupture into itself.
  • Malignant Hydatid cysts are caused by Echinococcus multilocularis

Explanation of other options:

Liver abscess (Option A): Usually appears as a hypoechoic lesion with internal echoes or debris, without serpiginous internal membranes.

HCC (Option C) shows Early enhancement and Rapid washout in triple-phase CT Scan, whereas the USG image is suggestive of a Hydatid cyst.

Cirrhosis (Option D) most commonly arises from Chronic alcohol abuse. Ultrasound is a major screening tool for cirrhosis and its complications. It includes: surface nodularity and heterogeneous echotexture, segmental hypertrophy/atrophy with signs of portal hypertension.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given image of the liver seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT image demonstrates a well-defined hepatic lesion with a central scar and homogeneous enhancement, typical of Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH).
  • FNH is a benign hyperplastic lesion, often asymptomatic and found incidentally, most commonly in young to middle-aged women.
  • The hallmark is a central stellate scar, which may show delayed enhancement on contrast imaging.
  • It enhances in the arterial phase due to its vascularity and becomes isodense in the portal venous phase.
  • Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a regenerative mass lesion of the liver and the second most common benign liver lesion (the most common is a hemangioma).
  • Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is most frequently found in young to middle-aged adults, with a strong female predilection.
  • FNH demonstrates bright homogeneous arterial contrast enhancement except for the central scar, which remains hypoattenuating. Enlarged central arteries may be seen.
  • Sulphur Colloid Scan can be used for further evaluation. FNH contains normal Kupffer cells and shows uptake of radiotracer on the scan, which helps differentiate it from other hepatic lesions like adenoma or metastases, which lack Kupffer cells and therefore show photopenic areas.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatic adenoma (Option B) usually presents as a solitary, well-demarcated, heterogeneous mass. A hypoechoic halo of focal fatty sparing is also frequently seen.

Metastases to the liver (Option C) show a target appearance of multiple lesions in the liver parenchyma. It is suggestive of liver metastasis.

HCC(Option D) shows Early enhancement and Rapid washout in triple-phase CT Scan,

choices.text: Take a biopsy from the lesion

questions.text: A patient with a recent history of weight loss and fatigue came to the OPD for routine follow-up. He underwent a USG examination of the abdomen. The images of the liver are shown below. The previous USG done 6 months ago showed a normal appearance of the liver. What should be the next best step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a target appearance of multiple lesions in the liver parenchyma. It is suggestive of liver metastasis. Hence, the next best step is to identify the primary tumour.

Further assessment of radiograph:

  • Hypoechoic: most common ~65%
    • lung cancer
    • breast cancer
    • pancreatic adenocarcinoma
    • lymphoma
  • hyperechoic
    • Colorectal carcinoma (CRC)
    • Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Kaposi sarcoma
    • Neuroendocrine tumors
    • Carcinoid
    • Pancreatic islet cell tumours
  • peripheral halo: a hypoechoic halo is a concerning feature, sometimes called the target or bull's eye lesion/sign
    • common in many lung cancer
  • calcified
    • mucinous adenocarcinoma
    • gastrointestinal
    • Ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma
  • cystic
    • squamous cell carcinoma
    • ovarian cancer
    • pancreatic adenocarcinoma
    • colorectal carcinoma (CRC)
  • poorly defined (infiltrative)
    • melanoma
    • breast cancer
    • lung cancer
  • associated intrahepatic biliary dilation
    • colorectal carcinoma (CRC)

Explanation of other options:

Nothing to be done (Option A): Not appropriate in a symptomatic patient with new multiple hepatic lesions.

Take a biopsy from the lesion (Option B): May be needed later, but identifying the primary tumour takes precedence.

Start antibiotics (Option D): No features suggestive of liver abscess or infection.

questions.text: Identify the ultrasound findings based on the image given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrygian cap is the most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder, characterised by a fold in the fundus that creates an appearance of a "cap."
  • On ultrasound, it presents as a fold between the body and fundus of the gallbladder, sometimes mimicking pathology.
  • It is a benign incidental finding with no clinical significance and requires no treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Duplicated Gallbladder (Option A) On ultrasound, MRCP, or CT: Two distinct gallbladder structures; can be complete or partial duplication

Gallbladder Polyp (Option C): On ultrasound, hyperechoic non-shadowing lesion attached to gallbladder wall; does not move with position change

Floating Gallbladder (Option D): On imaging, Gallbladder appears displaced from its normal fossa; may show twisting of cystic pedicle on CT or US

questions.text: A patient presented with the sudden onset of right upper quadrant pain and fever. On doing a USG, the following image of the liver and gallbladder was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute cholecystitis refers to the acute inflammation of the gallbladder. It is the primary complication of cholelithiasis and the most common cause of acute pain in the right upper quadrant (RUQ).
  • The most sensitive US finding in acute cholecystitis is the presence of cholelithiasis in combination with the sonographic Murphy sign.
  • Both gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm) and pericholecystic fluid are secondary findings.

Explanation of other options:-

Cholelithiasis (Option A) is a concretion that may occur anywhere within the biliary system, which can cause Cholecystitis as a complication.

Choledocholithiasis (Option C) refers to the presence of gallstones within the bile ducts, typically the common bile duct. Which can be assessed by ultrasound, the provided image does not demonstrate stones within the bile ducts. (MRCP and ERCP images given below)

Gallbladder cancer (Option D): Gallbladder cancer may present with thickening of the gallbladder wall, intraluminal masses, or irregularities in the gallbladder contour. While gallbladder cancer can sometimes mimic the appearance of gallstones on ultrasound, it typically presents with additional features such as focal wall thickening, mass lesions, or invasion into adjacent structures.

questions.text: Identify the following condition of the gallbladder.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ultrasound image shows characteristic features of adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder, including a thickened gallbladder wall and intramural diverticula (Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses).
  • These echogenic foci with comet-tail artefact are classical for adenomyomatosis.
  • It is a benign condition, often asymptomatic or may present with vague abdominal pain.

Explanation of other options:-

Gall Bladder calculi (Option A) shows Mercedes Benz sign on CT. Typically appear as echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing; no such shadow is seen here.

Gallbladder Polyp (Option B) is seen as an elevation of the gallbladder wall protruding into the lumen. Presents as an irregular mass replacing the gallbladder or wall thickening with infiltration.Posterior acoustic shadow is absent, differentiating itb from gall stones.

Porcelain Gallbladder (Option D) is a premalignant condition that has a premalignant potential to develop into Gallbladder Ca. Presents as an irregular mass replacing the gallbladder or wall thickening with infiltration.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows features of small bowel obstruction and air in biliary tree, suggestive of Gallstone ileus.
  • Gallstone ileus is a rare cause of mechanical small bowel obstruction, typically seen in elderly patients with a history of chronic cholecystitis.
  • It results from a cholecystoenteric fistula through which a gallstone passes and lodges in the ileum, most often near the ileocecal valve.
  • Radiographic findings include: Rigler's triad.
    • Evidence of small bowel obstruction (dilated loops with air-fluid levels),
    • Ectopic gallstone, and
    • Pneumobilia (air in the biliary tree).

Explanation of other options:

Gallbladder cancer (Option B): Gallbladder cancer may present with thickening of the gallbladder wall, intraluminal masses, or irregularities in the gallbladder contour. While gallbladder cancer can sometimes mimic the appearance of gallstones on ultrasound, it typically presents with additional features such as focal wall thickening, mass lesions, or invasion into adjacent structures.

Midgut volvulus (Option C) shows cork screw appearance sign which describes the spiral appearance of the distal duodenum and proximal jejunum seen in midgut volvulus.

Intussusception (Option D) is a condition in which one segment of intestine "telescopes" inside another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage). It will show the claw sign on barium studies and the target sign on USG.

Intussusception

choices.text: Stone in the common bile duct

questions.text: A patient presented with obstructive jaundice. On doing a USG, the following image is obtained of the liver. There is evidence of dilated intrahepatic biliary radicles and the common bile duct. What is the most likely diagnosis from the options given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ultrasound image shows dilated intrahepatic biliary radicles (IHBR), seen as tubular anechoic (dark) structures within the liver, indicating biliary obstruction.
  • In this case, the most likely cause of biliary obstruction is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD), i.e., Choledocholithiasis.
  • Choledocholithiasis denotes the presence of gallstones within the bile ducts
  • Ultrasound is usually the first investigation for biliary disease, with an average sensitivity

Findings include:

  • Visualisation of stone(s): Echogenic rounded focus
  • Dilated bile duct
    • >6 mm + 1 mm per decade above 60 years of age
    • >10 mm post-cholecystectomy
    • dilated intrahepatic biliary tree
  • The presence of gallstones should increase suspicion

Recently, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) has also been used for diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Cholelithiasis (Option A) may occur anywhere within the biliary system. This can cause cholecystitis as a complication, whereas the given USG image shows the presence of stones in the bile ducts, suggestive of choledocolithiasis.

Gallstone ileus (Option C) is a complication of chronic cholecystitis and occurs when a gallstone passes through a fistula between the gallbladder and small bowel before becoming impacted at the ileocecal valve. Whereas the given USG image shows the presence of stones in the bile ducts, suggestive of choledocholithiasis.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) (Option D) is a chronic cholestatic syndrome that is characterised by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree, resulting in chronic cholestasis. It leads to obliteration of both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree, leading to biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and liver failure.

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ERCP image shows a smooth, tapered narrowing of the distal common bile duct (CBD), which is a classic finding of a biliary stricture.

Biliary stricture

  • Biliary strictures may be benign (e.g., post-surgical, inflammatory) or malignant (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic cancer).
  • The absence of filling defects and lack of stent outline rules out choledocholithiasis and biliary stent, respectively.

Explanation of other options:

Biliary stent (Option B) would appear as a tubular radiopaque structure. The given ERCP image shows the presence of only the biliary stricture, which is managed further by the Biliary stenting.

Choledocholithiasis (Option C) refers to the presence of gallstones within the bile ducts, typically the common bile duct. Which can be assessed by ultrasound, the provided image does not demonstrate stones within the bile ducts. (MRCP and ERCP images given below)

Normal biliary structure (Option D): The distal narrowing seen here is abnormal and not a feature of normal biliary anatomy.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for biliary microlithiasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the most sensitive investigation for biliary microlithiasis, capable of detecting tiny stones and sludge in the bile duct and gallbladder.
  • Transabdominal USG may miss microlithiasis due to its limited resolution.
  • EUS combines endoscopy and high-frequency ultrasound, providing detailed images of the biliary tree.
  • EUS is particularly useful when other imaging is inconclusive in patients with recurrent biliary symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Trans abdominal USG (Option A): May miss microlithiasis; not as sensitive as EUS.

CT Scan (Option C): Limited sensitivity for small stones or sludge.

X-RAY (Option D): Cannot detect microlithiasis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with the acute onset of abdominal pain, mainly in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound abdomen was done and showed echogenic foci in the gall bladder. A CT Scan was performed, and the following image was obtained as shown below. What is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT scan image showsair in the gallbladder wall in an elderly diabetic patient, suggestive of Emphysematous Cholecystitis.
  • Emphysematous cholecystitis is a form of acute cholecystitis and a surgical emergency.
  • Carries a risk of gallbladder gangrene and perforation and high mortality.
  • Ultrasonography may demonstrate highly echogenic reflectors with low-level posterior shadowing and reverberation artefacts and champagne sign (echogenic foci rising from the lumen of the Gall bladder).
  • CT is considered the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for identifying gas within the gallbladder lumen or wall.
  • HIDA scan may demonstrate the RIM sign.

Explanation of other options:

Acute calculous cholecystitis (Option A): Gallbladder dilatation, gallstone obstructing the neck of the GB, wall thickening, sonographic "Murphy" sign.

Gallbladder cancer (Option B): Gallbladder cancer may present with thickening of the gallbladder wall, intraluminal masses, or irregularities in the gallbladder contour. While gallbladder cancer can sometimes mimic the appearance of gallstones on ultrasound, it typically presents with additional features such as focal wall thickening, mass lesions, or invasion into adjacent structures.

Porcelain gall bladder (Option D): A Thin layer of mineralisation (Calcification) outlining the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the right upper quadrant on the fifth post-operative day, following Lap-cholecystectomy. She is icteric, and on ultrasound, there is a collection seen in Morrison's pouch. Biliary leak is suspected. What is the most sensitive investigation to detect a biliary leak?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most sensitive Investigation to detect biliary leak is the HIDA scan.
  • The initial investigation to assess the biliary leak is an ultrasound.
  • The Gold standard to detect the anatomical site of bile leak is ERCP.
  • ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic for distal CBD stones.

HIDA scan findings in Biliary leak:

  • Radionuclide tracer extravasation: There is abnormal accumulation of tracer outside the expected biliary tree, indicating leakage.
  • Photopenic gallbladder area: In cases of cystic duct leak or gallbladder perforation, the gallbladder may not visualize (non-filling).
  • Tracer accumulation in peritoneal cavity or subhepatic space: This is visualized as progressive radioactivity beyond the confines of the biliary system.

Explanation of other options:

ERCP (Option A): Gold standard for identifying the anatomical site, but less sensitive in early detection.

MRCP (Option B): Non-invasive but less sensitive for detecting active bile leaks compared to HIDA.

CECT (Option D): Useful for detecting fluid collections but not specific for bile leaks.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presenting with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, jaundice, and fatigue underwent MRCP. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given MRCP image, which shows multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing, along with the given clinical features, is suggestive of Primary sclerosing cholangitis (Prune tree appearance).

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) -

  • PSC is a chronic cholestatic syndrome that is characterised by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree, resulting in chronic cholestasis.
  • It leads to obliteration of both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree, leading to biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and liver failure.
  • The patient usually presents with fatigue, pruritus, and upper abdominal pain.
  • Jaundice and icterus may also be present.
  • 70% cases are associated with IBD.

Explanation of other options:

Primary Biliary Cirrhosis (Option B): In CT, parenchymal lace-like fibrosis and periportal halo sign are seen together a sensitivity for primary biliary cholangitis.

Caroli's disease (Option C): Shows the central Dot sign. Caroli's Disease is a congenital disorder showing cystic dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts.

Recurrent pyogenic cholangiohepatitis (Option D), previously known as oriental cholangiohepatitis, is a condition characterised by intra- and extrahepatic bile duct strictures and dilatation with an intraductal pigmented stone formation.
